title: 107_s610
content: The Act may be cited as the "Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings. Congress finds that decommissioned firearms once used by law enforcement agencies have been involved in various crimes, including shootings near playgrounds and at a Jewish community center. Additionally, firearms stolen during shipment have been traced to crimes in Chicago. In Illinois, decommissioned firearms previously used by law enforcement have been linked to over 3,000 crimes in the past 9 years, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. State and local law enforcement departments also resell confiscated firearms, including assault weapons, that were involved in crimes prior to the 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 restricted assault weapons in circulation. Law enforcement departments in various states destroy decommissioned firearms to reduce the number of firearms on the streets. The purpose of this Act is to prevent the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 restricted assault weapons in circulation, with law enforcement departments destroying decommissioned firearms to prevent their transfer to individuals. SEC. 3. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms, as long as they have a policy against transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms, with a policy against transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals. States or local governments receiving grants must only use the funds to buy new firearms, except for transferring decommissioned firearms to law enforcement agencies. To apply for a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Regulations for the grants are also outlined. The Attorney General must create regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment, specifying information and requirements for grant applications. Additionally, reporting requirements are outlined in the Act. SEC. 6. REPORTING. A State or local government must report to the Attorney General within 2 years of receiving funds under this Act on its implementation. The report must include budget assurances for law enforcement agencies to purchase firearms without transferring decommissioned ones. SEC. 7. DEFINITION. Defines "decommissioned firearm" as a firearm no longer in use by law enforcement or involved in a crime, and "firearm" and "person" as per specific legal definitions. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005.
